Rationale

The  Environment  and  Social  Program  will  assist  the  Lao  PDR  to
implement  a  policy  reform  agenda  for  environmental  management
and social safeguards  in  the  energy  and  transport  sectors,  focusing
on hydropower and roads.

The  Lao  PDR  is  a  small  landlocked  country,  characterized  by
mountainous  terrain,  low  population  density,  limited  skilled  human
resources,  and  a  wealth  of  natural  resources  and  environmental
assets.  As  natural  resources  underpin  economic  development  and
poverty  reduction  prospects,  the  Government  attaches  priority  to
conserving  the  environment  and  ensuring  the  environmental  and
social sustainability of all development activities.

Improving  environmental  management  and  social  safeguards
performance  has  been  the  subject  of  considerable  policy  dialogue
and  technical  assistance.  Enactment  of  the  Environment  Protection
Law (EPL) in 1999 was a breakthrough. Together with environmental
provisions  in  laws  on  electricity,  roads,  land,  water  resources,  and
forests, the EPL provides a framework for implementing safeguards.
However,  effective  enforcement  requires  the  adoption  of  enabling
regulations,  compliance  mechanisms,  and  measures  to  enhance
Government capacity and financial sustainability. Without these, the
integration  of  environmental  management  and  social  safeguard
issues across sectors will remain elusive.

The Government aims to go beyond case-by-case remedial action on
environmental and social impacts, toward a proactive approach that
integrates  these  concerns  within  national,  sectoral,  and  area-based
planning.  The  Government  has  sought  Asian  Development  Bank
(ADB)  assistance  to  develop  and  implement  a  program  aimed  at
putting  the  country  on  a  more  sustainable  development  trajectory,
focusing initially on the energy and transport sectors. This will require
addressing  five  closely  related  sets  of  constraints:  (i)  incomplete
policy and regulatory framework; (ii) lack of implementation capacity
at  sectoral  and  provincial  levels;  (iii)  inadequate  compliance  and
enforcement  mechanisms;  (iv)  absence  of  integrated  area-based
planning  frameworks  to  guide  investments  in  energy  and  transport;
and (v) insufficient attention to sustainable finance for environmental
management.

In September 2000, the Government of the Lao PDR requested the Asian Development

B.

Recent Economic Performance and Prospects

4.
Macroeconomic instability in 1997-1999, triggered by the regional crisis and exacerbated
by  expansionary  fiscal  policies,  threatened  to  undermine  economic  development.  Foreign
investment  inflows  and  Government  revenues  dropped  sharply  after  1997.  Tighter  fiscal  and
monetary  policies  from  mid-1999  helped  to  stabilize  the  economy  and,  despite  three  years  of
economic  instability,  economic  growth  averaged  6.2  percent  per  annum  during  the  last  five
years.  Annual  inflation  fell  from  128  percent  in  1999  to  less  than  10  percent  by  mid-2001.
Despite recent improvement, average per capita income was only about $330 in 2000. The Lao
PDR  and  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  entered  into  an  agreement  for  loan  financing
under IMF’s Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility in April 2001. Successful implementation of
the reforms agreed-upon under this facility will lay the foundation for greater economic stability,
and more sustainable and equitable economic growth.

5.
The  Government  targets  broad-based  economic  growth  of  7.0–7.5  percent  per  annum
over the next five years. Past performance and regional experience suggest this is an ambitious
target,  not  the  least  in  the  context  of  the  international  economic  slowdown.  In  the  longer  term
such  growth  rates  may  be  achievable,  but  would  require  that  the  following  challenges  be
addressed:  developing  a  competitive  and  open  market  economy,  improving  labor  productivity
through  improved  health  and  education,  and  strengthening  the  capacity  to  deliver  more
sustainable  benefits  from  the  management  of  natural  resources  and  the  environment.  Recent
initiatives  to  attenuate  policy,  institutional,  and  infrastructure  constraints  to  regional  integration
provide  improved  opportunities  for  investments  in  energy,  transport,  trade,  tourism,  and  other
services.  In  particular,  the  Lao  PDR  is  well  placed  to  develop  energy  as  a  major  source  of
export earnings due to its substantial hydropower resources and strategic location. To achieve
national  socioeconomic  development  goals  in  public  finance  and  investment  appropriate
environmental  management  and  social  safeguards  can  help  attract  the  necessary  increased
commercial investments from established international investors.

C.

Public Finance and Investment

6.
A major challenge in realizing development goals is the domestic resource constraints to
financing  recurrent  and  development  expenditure.  Weaknesses  in  tax  collection,  public
expenditure planning and management, and reliance on official development assistance (ODA)
financing  of  public  capital  expenditure  remain  problematic.  The  Government  recognizes  that  it
will need to attract increased private investment to help bridge the domestic investment-savings
gap in financing its ambitious development agenda. This is particularly important because of the
urgent  need  to  increase  the  share  of  current  spending  in  total  public  expenditure  so  as  to
ensure the sustainability of capital investments. This need for increased current expenditure is
particularly  evident  in  the  social  sectors,  and  also  for  environmental  management  purposes.
The  current  capital/current  expenditure  ratio  is  partly  the  result  of  a  very  high  dependence  on
external financing of budget expenditure. The Government targets call for an increase in current
expenditure from 6.1 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1999 to more than 10 percent
in 2003.

7.

but the Government recognizes that the only sustainable solution is to increase public revenue.
The  external  financing  gap  is  currently  projected  at  about  $110 million  during FY2001/03.4

D.

The Socioeconomic Setting

8.
The  Lao  PDR  ranks  132nd  out  of  162  countries  according  to  the  United  Nations
Development Programme's (UNDP’s) 2001 human development index. Poverty incidence in the
Lao  PDR  declined  from  45  percent  in  FY1992/93  to  39  percent  in  FY1997/98,  but  there  is
considerable  disparity  in  poverty  incidence  across  regions  and  provinces  as  well  as  between
urban and rural areas. The concentration of poor and ultrapoor households and communities is
highest in the northern provinces and lowest in Vientiane Municipality. The incidence of poverty
is  greatest  among  communities  in  rural,  more  remote,  and  mountainous  areas.  While
consumption  inequality  is  less  than  that  in  many  other  Asian  countries,  it  has  increased
markedly in the last five years. The Gini coefficient increased from 28.7 percent in FY1992/93 to
34.3  percent  in  FY1997/98.  According  to  the  2001  participatory  poverty  assessment  (PPA),
poverty  in  the  Lao  PDR  is  generally  linked  to  livelihood  systems,  including  agriculture  and
forestry  production,  rural  infrastructure,  basic  education,  and  primary  health  care.  Most  of  the
population  depend  directly  on  natural  resources  for  their  livelihood.  Poorer  communities  are
especially vulnerable to negative environmental and social impacts of large-scale infrastructure
development  projects.  Improved  management  of  environmental  and  social  concerns  will  be
essential to protect and improve the livelihoods of the poor and to increase the options available
for poverty reduction. This is important in an economy where a few large hydropower projects
are  likely  to  dominate  export  earnings  and  budget  revenue,  but  will  create  relatively  few  jobs
directly.

A.

Background

1. 

Environment

The  Lao  PDR  has  a  land  area  of  236,800  square  kilometers  (km2),  bounded  by
9.
Myanmar  to  the  northwest,  People’s  Republic  of  China  to  the  north,  Viet  Nam  to  the  east,
Cambodia  to  the  south,  and  Thailand  to  the  west.  Two  main  physical  features,  rivers  and
mountains,  dominate  the  topography,  and  their  interaction  accounts  for  most  of  the  country’s
geographic,  biological,  and  social  variation.  A  total  of  1,865  km  of  the  4,000  km  long  Mekong
River flows through the Lao PDR or along its border with Thailand. The Lao PDR contributes 26
percent of the drainage area of the Mekong River and 40 percent of its water resources, thereby

 4

making the country the largest single contributor of water to the Mekong River. The country also
has the largest per capita volume of freshwater at 66,000 cubic meters/person, which amounts
to 20 times the regional average.

A  broad  range  of  natural  systems  representing  many  vegetation  types  is  found  in  the
10.
country.  These  are  a  variety  of  forest  types,  grasslands,  water  bodies,  and  wetlands,  all  of
which are habitats for a wide range of wildlife. Most of the indigenous vegetation in the Lao PDR
is associated with forests. According to official data from the National Forest Inventory, forests
cover  approximately  11.2  million  hectares,  or  47.2  percent  of  the  country.  The  dominant
evergreen  forest  types  are  dry  or  semievergreen  forests  and  hill  evergreen  forests.  The
dominant  forest  types  are  mixed  deciduous.  About  half  of  these  woodlands  –  a  very  high
proportion  –  can  be  classified  as  primary  forest,  while  another  30  percent  or  so  represent
secondary growth. The Lao PDR ranks 11th in the world in terms of percentage of natural forest
cover. However, deforestation is occurring at an annual rate of 0.6-0.8 percent.

11.
Forests,  wetlands,  and  other  natural  areas  harbor  approximately  10,000  species  of
animals and vascular plants. Within Southeast Asia, the Lao PDR is second only to Cambodia
in the number of species by land area. Twenty-five species found in the Lao PDR are globally
endangered.  Most  of  the  fauna  belongs  to  the  Indochina  zoogeographic  realm.  In  terms  of
faunal  biodiversity,  the Wildlife  in  Lao  PDR:  1999  Status  Report  produced  by  the  World
Conservation  Union  (IUCN)  states  that  319  out  of  1,140  species  included  in  the  review  are
significant for national or global conservation, i.e., 67 percent of the large mammals, 53 percent
of the bats, 6 percent of the insectivora, 14 percent of the murid rodents, 22 percent of the birds,
25  percent  of  the  reptiles,  and  2  percent  of  the  amphibians.  The  Lao  PDR  is  thought  to  have
some of the last populations of Javan rhinoceros, kouprey, and Siamese crocodiles in the world.
Three large mammal species new to science were discovered in the Lao PDR and neighboring
areas of Viet Nam in the past decade, an unparalleled event in modern science. The Lao PDR
has established 20 national biodiversity conservation areas (NBCAs) covering 13 percent of the
country.

12.
The  population  of  the  Lao  PDR  consists  of  some  48  distinct  ethnolinguistic  groups
comprising  three  main  groups  who  respectively  populate  the  lowlands,  the  medium  altitudes,
and  the  more  remote  highlands  and  mountainous  areas.  Each  group  has  developed  a
significant culture, knowledge, and experience that is tailored to the natural resources available
to  them,  and  that  is  reflected  in  their  dominant  livelihood  systems.  These  groups  have  strong
ties to the land and natural resource base. Forests and rivers provide the rural people with food
plants,  meat,  medicines,  fish,  resins,  building  materials,  and  other  products  for  domestic

household food insecurity, and when natural disasters occur.

14.
The  EPL  stipulates  the  fundamental  principles,  regulations,  and  measures  required  for
preserving  and  managing  the  environment  as  well  as  for  the  efficient  and  sustainable  use  of
natural resources. The fundamental principles of the EPL include (i) emphasizing environmental
conservation  before  mitigation  and  restoration,  (ii)  integrating  environmental  protection  into
socioeconomic development planning, (iii) requiring all persons and organizations to contribute
to  environmental  protection,  (iv)  requiring  those  who  cause  damage  to  the  environment  to  be
responsible for mitigation and compensation, and (v) avoiding pollution and waste through the
careful  use  of  natural  resources.  The  EPL  also  foresees  the  establishment  of  an  environment
protection fund to finance environmental management activities.

15.
The  EPL  assigns  to  the  Science,  Technology,  and  Environment  Agency  (STEA)  the
mandate  to  monitor  and  coordinate  all  environment-related  actions.  STEA  coordinates  and

hydropower  development.  STEA  also  prepares,  coordinates,  oversees,  and  monitors
environmental  policies,  regulations,  and  guidelines,  and  the  preparation  and  dissemination  of

Coordinating  Committee  (WRCC)  and  provides  the  secretariat  for  the  Interministerial  Working
Group  on  Environment  (IMWGE).  The  WRCC,  formed  in  1998  with  STEA  as  chair,  is  tasked
with coordinating activities associated with the Water and Water Resources Law and includes
all major ministries in its membership. The IMWGE is a mid-level group that meets occasionally
to discuss technical issues related to environmental management.

16.

sectors,  including  electricity,  geology,  mines,  and  industry  and  handicrafts.  MIH  is  responsible

and  industrial  waste.  The  Ministry  of  Communication,  Transport,  Post  and  Construction

development, and administers the associated EIA process.

17.
The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  has  a  crucial  role  in  promoting  the
sustainable  use  of  natural  resources  (soil,  forest,  water,  fish,  and  biodiversity)  for  rural
development.  The  Ministry  of  Justice  has  wide-ranging  influence  in  preparing,  enforcing,  and
monitoring  all  laws,  decrees,  and  guidelines,  including  those  dealing  with  social  and

national  planning  processes.  Augmenting  CPC’s  role  are  the  National  Land  Use  and  Forest

have  important  roles  in  involuntary  resettlement  and  compensation  procedures,  especially  in

2. 

The Energy Sector

18.
The  Lao  PDR  has  a  technically  exploitable  hydropower  potential  of  about  18,000
megawatts (MW), of which 623 MW of generation capacity has been developed through seven
hydropower  plants.  Public  investment  has  financed  the  development  of  263  MW, with two

 6

independent  power  producers  (IPPs),  Theun  Hinboun  (210  MW)  and  Houay  Ho  (150  MW),
accounting  for  the  remainder.  The  country's  rich  hydropower  resource  endowment  already
provides  an  important  source  of  foreign  exchange  earnings  and  budget  revenue.  Annual
Government  revenues  from  electricity  exports  are  expected  to  increase  from  $44.9  million  in
2000  to  $136  million  in  2010.  However,  opportunities  for  tapping  the  remaining  potential  are
tempered  by  the  emergence  of  competing  energy  sources  in  export  markets,  a  less  buoyant
investment  climate,  and  legitimate  social  and  environmental  concerns  about  inappropriate
hydropower  development.  The  Lao  PDR  has  one  of  the  lowest  levels  of  electrification  in  Asia
with only 30 percent of the population and 2 percent of rural households connected to the power
grid.  Low  domestic  tariff  rates  mean  that  export  sales  are  subsidizing  the  few,  mostly  urban,
domestic consumers who are connected to the power grid.

Overall  responsibility  for  the  power  sector  is  vested  in  the  Department  of  Electricity
19.
(DOE) in MIH. Under the Electricity Law (approved 1997), DOE is responsible for preparing and
implementing  sector  legislation  and  regulations,  overseeing  the  performance  of  electricity
enterprises, and for  formulating policies and strategic planning. Within DOE, the Hydro Power
Office (HPO) is responsible for strategic power planning, identifying projects, and evaluating IPP
project  proposals,  while  the  Rural  Electrification  Division  is  the  focal  unit  for  off-grid
electrification.  A  small  environmental  management  and  monitoring  unit  is  attached  to  HPO.
Electricité du Lao (EdL), a state-owned corporation, develops, and partly owns and operates the
country’s  main  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution  assets;  and  manages  electricity
imports to its grids and exports from its stations. Responsibility for off-grid projects rests with the
relevant local authorities or concessionaires. The Lao National Committee for Energy manages
the  development  and  marketing  of  export  power  projects  and  negotiates  on  behalf  of  the
Government. It monitors and reports on power sector issues. The Electricity Law requires that
all  projects  greater  than  50  MW  be  approved  by  the  Government  and  the  National  Assembly,
and  that  all  projects  between  2  and  50  MW  be  licensed  by  the  Government.  Smaller  projects
can be licensed by the relevant local authorities.

20.
Eleven  major  hydropower  projects,  with  a  total  design  capacity  of  4,000  MW,  are  in  the
planning or advanced planning stage for implementation during the next 10 years. Eight projects
are  expected  to  be  built  on  an  IPP/build-operate-transfer  basis.  The  total  capital  cost  of  the
currently proposed IPP projects over the period to 2010 is about $5 billion in current prices, with
another  $350  million  required  to  develop  a  500-kilovolt  (kV)  line  to  Thailand.  However,  it  is
unlikely that all projects will be implemented in the next decade. Preparations for the largest IPP,
Nam  Theun  2  (1,088  MW),  are  well  advanced  and  construction  is  expected  to  be  completed  in
2006. EdL plans to develop four of the smaller projects.

B.

Environmental Management and Social Safeguard Issues and Constraints

1.

Issues

24.
Natural  resources  play  a  central  role  in  the  economy  of  the  Lao  PDR.  Forestry
contributes  7-10  percent  of  GDP  and  is  the  only  major  agricultural  export.  Water  resources
(through  hydropower  generation)  now  account  for  an  important  share  of  foreign  exchange
earnings. Hydropower export earnings are expected to remain a major source of growth in the
fiscal  revenues  needed  to  fund  service  delivery  and  basic  infrastructure  to  improve  health,
education, and other social services. Rural access roads, designed with appropriate safeguards
and  nested  within  integrated  rural  development  strategies,  can  promote  resource-based
economic  development  and  reduce  poverty.  They  can  simultaneously  decrease  pressure  on
natural resources by providing access to markets, services, and technology that allow farmers
to intensify agriculture and turn away from sometimes destructive shifting cultivation practices.
Appropriately  designed  roads  can  also  provide  opportunities  for  ecotourism  development,
including access to NBCAs for tourists whose user fees can contribute to their protection.

The quality and productivity of the natural resource base is also vital to the well-being of
25.
rural communities, which account for 85 percent of the country’s population. Forests and rivers
provide rural people with food plants, meat, medicines, fish, resins, building materials, and other
products  for  home  consumption  and  income  generation.  Fish  harvested  from  rivers  and  other
wetlands provide a significant proportion of total animal protein consumed in the country. These
natural “all-purpose shops” serve a vital social security function, especially during times of rice

 8

deficit and when natural calamities decimate agricultural harvests. For many rural households,
access to these resources can mean the difference between maintaining their homes and being
forced to move to new lands or urban areas.

Experience  in  the  Lao  PDR  confirms  that  road  and  hydropower  projects  can  pose
26.
substantial environmental and social risks. Many such risks are associated with direct impacts
in the projects’ zones of influence that result from decisions regarding project location, design,
and  construction  activities.  Such  impacts  are  in  principle  identifiable,  if  not  always  easily
avoided  or  mitigated.  Risks  include  loss  of  forest  cover;  changes  in  hydrological  regimes,
deterioration in water quality, and loss of fisheries; degraded agricultural land due to riverbank
erosion  or  displacement  by  alternative  development;  and  involuntary  resettlement,  social
dislocation, and impingement on rural livelihood systems.

27.
Indirect impacts during project implementation are similar, but often more insidious and
longer term in nature. They may include widespread environmental degradation, including loss
of watershed cover and a collapse of river ecology. Profound changes to community health and
cultural traditions may be induced due to new or improved access to previously isolated areas:
increased  illegal  trafficking  in  women  and  children;  spread  of  infectious  diseases  such  as
sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV/AIDS;5 and unplanned development and in-
migration that displace, marginalize, or impoverish existing communities.

28. Where environmental and social impacts are not foreseen and addressed appropriately,
the outcomes can undermine national development goals and contribute to increased economic
and social hardship among the affected populations. Populations most affected by hydropower
and  roads  developments  are  often  subsistence  ethnic  minority  communities  living  in  the  least
accessible  parts  of  the  country.  They  often  have  little  capacity  to  cope  with  potential  adverse
impacts that large infrastructure projects can have on production, productive assets and income
sources;  community  structures,  social  networks,  and  cultural  identity.  Infrastructure  projects
disperse kin and other mutual support groups; and introduce new diseases and/or aggravating
endemic diseases such  as malaria,  dysentery, and measles. Given the fragile nature of these
communities and the resources on which they depend, even minor impacts can result in severe
and long-term economic and social hardships that exacerbate their impoverishment.

29.
The  recently  conducted  PPA  identified  relocation  due  to  development  projects  as  a
direct  cause  of  poverty  in  some  communities.  The  Houay  Ho  project  is  one  example  of  a
completed  hydropower  project  with  no  resettlement  plan,  resulting  in  people  suffering  from  a
severe  shortage  of  food  and  arable  land,  and  insufficient  water  supply.  Remedial  action  to
alleviate the most pressing hardships was finally undertaken in 1999 at an approximate cost of
$2.4 million.6 Likewise, the ADB-financed Theun-Hinboun Hydropower Project7 has decreased
fisheries  and  fundamentally  changed  water  regimes,  thereby  affecting  the  capability  of  about
3,000  households  to  maintain  their  pre-project  livelihoods.  Late  mitigation  can  be  costly,  as
evidenced  by  the  $5  million  budget  required  for  the  new  Theun-Hinboun  mitigation  plan.  The
costs  of  fishery  and  terrestrial  habitat  loss  in  the  Nam  Kading  NBCA  downstream  of  the  dam
have yet to be fully assessed.

30.
The  problems  associated  with  previous  hydropower  development  projects  must  be
avoided  in  the  future.  Reactive  responses  to  correct  problems  are  not  in  the  national  interest.

Unless  measures  are  carefully  planned  and  implemented,  poverty  reduction  efforts  will  be

multilateral sources.

31.
There  are  also  regional  and  international  dimensions  to  these  risks.  The  way  natural
resources  are  used  in  the  Lao  PDR  can  have  strong  ripple  effects  in  neighboring  countries.
Thailand  now  imports  2,682  gigawatt-hours  (GWh)  of  power  from  the  Lao  PDR  and
understandings has been reached for future imports requiring an additional generating capacity
of 1,500–3,300 MW. Cambodia and Viet Nam rely on the Lao PDR to protect its rivers, fisheries,
and  forested  uplands  from  development  activities  that  could  profound  by  impact  on  the  diet,
commerce,  and  safety  of  large  downstream  populations.  Plans  to  develop  ecotourism  in  the
Greater  Mekong  subregion  will  fall  short  of  expectations  if  the  country  is  unable  to  attract
tourists  due  to  degraded  landscapes  and  decreasing  wildlife.  At  an  international  level,  Lao
PDR’s  stewardship  of  internationally  endangered  species  and  biodiversity  conservation  are
central to global environmental objectives. Emerging concerns are also being expressed about
the  potential  incremental  emission  of  greenhouse  gases  from  reservoirs  due  to  rotting
vegetation and carbon inflows from the catchments.

32.
Indications  of  the  magnitude  of  potential  problems  are  detailed  in  the  Lao  PDR
hydropower  development  strategy  which  estimated  that  16  of  the  30  potential  hydropower
development  sites  would  affect  NBCAs  and/or  areas  of  significant  biodiversity  value.  If
implemented,  projects  would  affect  varying  numbers  of  people.  Together,  the  projects  could
involve  the  relocation  of  33,000  people.  Transmission  lines,  access  roads,  or  construction
activities could affect another 14,000 people. Another 390,000 people downstream, and another
190,000  upstream  in  immediate  catchment  areas  could  also  be  affected  (footnote  5).  The
hydropower strategy study estimates that the total cost of social and environmental impacts for
these projects could be between $770 million and $2.8 billion, depending on the standards that
are followed. While few of the 30 potential sites may be developed within the foreseeable future,
and many will never be developed, the estimates from the study are illustrative.

33.
Road  transport  sector  development  plans  call  for  some  $734  million  to  be  invested  in
developing and maintaining the road network over the next 10 years. Past experience with road
development in the Lao PDR suggests that, without substantial improvements in planning and
mitigation  measures  to  address  environmental  and  social  concerns,  the  potential  social  and
environmental  impacts  of  future  road  developments  are  likely  to  be  significant.  Without
improved safeguards, there are strong risks of increased erosion, illegal logging, deforestation,
and  biodiversity  losses,  and  there  will  be  inadequate  safeguards  for  persons  or  communities
adversely  affected  by  road  development.  Failure  to  implement  improved  planning,  public
consultations,  environmental  management,  and  social  safeguards  in  the  road  sector  would
mean that potential synergies in public investment will be lost, and potential benefits, especially
in terms of reducing poverty and increasing economic opportunities, will not be fully realized.

A  river  basin  planning  approach  will  allow  policy  makers  to  optimize  the  benefits  of
34.
natural resource management within the whole basin—from upper watersheds that are prone to
erosion,  to  lower  plains  that   are  affected  by  frequent  floods. In  the  longer term,  such  an

management  and  soil  conservation,  flood  protection  and  mitigation,  fisheries  preservation  and

been  optimized  in  the  past  due  mainly  to  lack  of  a  legal  framework  that  will  govern  the  water

development can be avoided or managed.

b. 

Weak Capacity at Sector and Subnational Levels

38. Weak  or  nonexistent  capacity  for  social  and  environmental  protection  is  a  reality  in  all
development  sectors.  The  situation  needs  urgent  improvement,  especially  in  the  hard  sectors
where  the  scope  and  magnitude  of  impacts  are  wide-ranging,  significant,  and  sometimes
irreversible. In addition to creating direct impacts on the environment and people's lives, major
infrastructure  projects  can  alter  the  dynamics  of  natural  resource  management  and  livelihood
systems at a local level and can have a profound influence on the spatial patterns of agricultural
and  rural  development.  Generally,  mechanisms  for  integrating  the  environment  into  strategic
planning  are  absent,  procedures  are  not  clear,  guidelines  not  formalized,  and  criteria  not
disclosed. The relevant line agencies have neither formally adopted sector-specific regulations
nor issued guidelines. They also lack the corresponding institutional arrangements to coherently
address the issues from a project-specific, let alone strategic planning, perspective.

39.
In  the  energy  and  transport  sectors  specifically,  some  progress  has  been  made  in  EIA
training and the drafting of EIA guidelines, and practical experience has been gained in working
with multilateral financed projects. Technical assistance has been useful, although it has been
fragmented and not always tailored precisely to meet institutional needs. Against this backdrop,
MIH and MCTPC continue to deal with environmental and social concerns on a reactive and ad
hoc basis depending on the specific due diligence requirements, if any, of the private sector and
aid  agencies.  Sector-specific  ministerial  guidance  on  project-related  involuntary  resettlement
and  compensation  is  absent,  and  public  involvement  procedures  are  lacking.  Although
rudimentary  environment  units  have  been  established  within  the  two  ministries  and  are
beginning  to  play  a  useful  role,  they  are  not  yet  equipped  with  the  relevant  institutional
mandates, appropriate human resources, and necessary budget to perform an adequate job.

40. While  more  effective  institutional  arrangements  for  environmental  policy  and  regulation
will  continue  to  be  needed  at  the  central  level,  the  absence  of  fully  functioning  provincial  and
district institutions is a cause for concern. The EPL assigns to agencies at subnational level a
substantial role in managing the environment and in enforcing safeguards; however, under the
Government's  decentralization  strategy,  provincial  agencies  are  called  upon  to  perform  a
number  of  mandates,  and  provincial  budgetary  processes  have  not  tended  to  favor
environmental  regulatory  functions  over  other  competing  priorities.  As  a  result,  provincial
science, technology, and environment offices (STEOs) have been created in several provinces,
but  are  not  in  a  position  to  discharge  their  responsibilities  under  the  EPL.  One  such
responsibility  is  preparing  of  provincial  environmental  action  plans,  which  could  provide  a
reasoned  and  credible  basis  for  prioritizing  tasks  and  allocating resources across agencies

 12

concerned with environmental management. In addition, the functional linkages and distribution
of tasks between STEA and the STEOs need to be further clarified.

c.

Insufficient Compliance and Enforcement

41.
There is a need to promote compliance with and enforcement of the EPL and other laws
with provisions for environmental management. Lack of awareness among civil society and the
Government  of  environmental  and  social  safeguards  embodied  in  the  law  is  one  fundamental
constraint.  A  related  constraint  is  lack  of  codification  and  knowledge  of  legal  mandates  and
implications of the EPL; legal recourse for enforcement and compliance; and civil and criminal
sanctions such as warnings, fines, revocation of licenses, civil sanctions, and criminal charges.

In  the  energy  and  transport  sectors,  measures  are  needed  to  enhance  transparency,
42.
predictability,  accountability,  oversight,  and  control.  The  adoption  and  application  of  sectoral
regulations  and  guidelines  on  EIA,  involuntary  resettlement  and  compensation,  and  public
involvement will be necessary, but not sufficient conditions. MIH and MCTPC need to ensure a
satisfactory  compliance  record  in  their  respective  sectors.  Neither  agency  currently  tracks
compliance  on  a  systematic  basis,  nor  issues  sector  compliance  reports.  In  response  to  the
requirements of project financiers, the Government has on occasion accepted third-party project
monitoring  arrangements.  These  arrangements  have  been  tested  in  the  case  of  the  World
Bank-supported  Nam  Theun  2  Hydropower  Project,  the  ADB-financed  Nam  Leuk  Hydropower
Project,  and  the  recently  approved  Rural  Access  Roads  Project.9  However,  the  Government
currently  lacks  an  established  system  and  procedures  for  third-party  monitoring  that  would  be
required  for  all  sensitive  projects.  The  Government  could  also  usefully  explore  new  and
innovative ways of achieving compliance. One option is the use of performance bonds that will
be an incentive for developers and contractors to implement environmental and social mitigation
measures and will provide insurance in the event of noncompliance.

e.

Lack of Sustainable Financing

46.
A  continuing  constraint  to  implementing  the  country’s  development  strategy  is  poor
domestic  resource  mobilization  and  utilization.  Budget  revenues  are  low  as  a  percentage  of
GDP and, despite recent improvements, weaknesses remain in public investment planning and
public  expenditure  management.  These  constraints,  coupled  with  a  high  dependence  on
external  assistance,  have  resulted  in  inordinate  imbalances  between  current  and  capital
expenditure.  Limited  availability  of  current  budget  resources  constrain  social  service  delivery,
and means that public infrastructure is often underutilized and poorly maintained. Compounding
these  problems  is  the  lack  of  systematic  incorporation  of  environmental  management
considerations  in  sector  planning,  public  investment  planning,  and  public  expenditure
monitoring.  Appropriate  planning  to  address  environmental  concerns  is  constrained  by  lack  of
information  on  national  and  provincial-level  spending  on  the  environment.  Given  the  limited
resources  and  a  growing  focus  on  allocating  limited  public  resources  to  human  development
and  poverty  reduction,  the  Government  wants  to  attract  increased  private  sector  financing  for
hydropower  and  transport  sector  development.  Recent  economic  difficulties  and  institutional
weaknesses  leave  policy  makers  especially  vulnerable  to  pressures  to  accept  investment
arrangements  that  may  be  suboptimal  in  terms  of  long-term  sustainable  development.
Procedural  and  regulatory  reforms,  combined  with  capacity  building  and  human  resource
development,  are  required  to  mitigate  these  risks.  However,  lack  of  adequate  financial
resources  for  critical  environmental  management  and  regulatory  tasks  will  constrain  the

V. 

THE PROGRAM

60.
The  Lao  PDR  is  a  small  landlocked  country  with  mountainous  terrain,  low  population
density,  limited  pool  of  skilled  human  resources,  and  a  wealth  of  natural  resources  and
environmental  assets,  including  globally  significant  biodiversity.  The  Government  aims  to
transform and diversify the country's predominantly resource-based economy while maintaining
macroeconomic  stability  and  promoting  economic  growth.  The  country's  economy  depends
primarily  on  natural  resources  in  the  forest,  mining,  tourism,  fisheries,  agriculture,  and
hydropower  sectors.  Since  natural  resources  underpin  economic  development  and  poverty
reduction  prospects,  the  Government  is  acutely  aware  of  the  importance  of  conserving
environmental  resources  and  ensuring  the  environmental  and  social  sustainability  of  all
development activities.

Adoption  of  a  policy  and  regulatory  framework  for  environmental  management  and
61.
social safeguards has been the subject of considerable policy dialogue and TA over the last few
years.  A  major  accomplishment  has  been  the  enactment  of  the  EPL,  which  together  with
relevant  environmental  provisions  in  the  laws  on  electricity,  roads,  land,  water  resources  and
forests,  provides  a  relatively  sound  basis  for  environmental  management  in  the  country.  The
next  phase  in  pursuing  environmental  conservation  and  ensuring  effective  enforcement  of  the
EPL  will  require  the  adoption  of  an  enabling  framework  for  regulation  and  compliance,
supported by measures to enhance Government capacity and address financial and institutional
sustainability. Without such a framework, the adequate integration of environmental and social
issues across all sectors will remain elusive.

62.

cross-sectoral,  and  long-term  social  and  environmental  impacts,  have  often  lacked  effective

The Government wants to make a transition from essentially reactive and case-by-case

PROGRAM BENEFITS AND RISKS

A.

Impacts and Benefits

The  Program  will  strengthen  the  policy  and  regulatory  framework  for  environmental
103.
management  and  social  safeguards;  enhance  institutional  capacity  at  sectoral  and  provincial
levels  to  identify,  analyze,  and  address  social  and  environmental  issues;  bolster  compliance
with  and  enforcement  of  laws  and  regulations;  foster  improved  sector  planning  within  an
integrated  natural  resource  management  framework;  and  promote  sustained  financing  for
priority environmental management activities.

104.
The  Program  will  reduce  or  avoid  the  high  social  and  environmental  costs  of
inappropriately  designed  infrastructure  development  in  the  energy  and  transport  sectors.  This
will result from the strategic environment assessment at the level of the PIP, improved upstream
planning  of  sectoral  development  and  reconciliation  of  competing  uses  of  natural  resources
within  a  river  basin  context,  better  policy  integration  across  the  sectors,  and  more  systematic
attention  to  environmental  and  social  safeguards  in  project  preparation  and  implementation.
Stricter enforcement, combined with incentives for compliance such as performance bonds, will
facilitate  internalization  of  externalities.  Recent  analysis  shows  that  the  actual  costs  of
resettlement can be 5-10 times higher than the amounts provided by developers. Where social
and environmental costs cannot be avoided, more equitable distribution of these costs will result
from  inclusion  of  appropriate  mitigation  measures  in  project  design.  This  will  help  ensure  that
social  and  environmental  costs  will  be  borne,  not  by  the  local  communities  but  by  the  project
developers.

105.
Introducing a coherent and more transparent regulatory framework for addressing social
and  environmental  concerns  will  reduce  uncertainty  and  delays  associated  with  investment  in
large infrastructure projects in the Lao PDR. This in turn will help make projects more attractive
to potential investors. It will also provide an enabling environment for international investors with
global  reputations  to  protect.  Such  investors  will  often  prefer  a  regulatory  framework  that
ensures that environmental and social mitigation activities can be planned and implemented in a
predictable manner, with clear definition of the rights and obligations of all partners.

106.
Implementing  public  participation  guidelines  will  substantially  improve  the  identification
of  potential  environmental  and  social  issues  associated  with  infrastructure  developments,  and
the  design  of  appropriate  measures  to  address  these  concerns.  Improved  public  participation
will  also  generate  additional  economic  benefits  by  (i)  creating  a  better  understanding  of  local
conditions, which will facilitate improved project designs, reduce risks, and increase efficiency;
(ii)  identifying  opportunities  to  maximize  economic  benefits  from  infrastructure  developments;
(iii) enhancing a sense of ownership and sustainability of new infrastructure; and (iv) increasing
the accountability of developers and contractors.

107.
The Program will enhance prospects for adequate and sustained allocation of resources
for  environmental  management  and  social  safeguards  by  introducing  of  user  fees  for
environmental services and establishing the environment fund. It will also increase the efficiency
of  resource  use  through  prioritization  and  improved  budgetary  processes  that  properly  reflect
the  requirements  of  sectoral  and  provincial  agencies  concerned  with  environmental
management and the implementation of social safeguards.

B.

Risks and Safeguards

111. A strong political will and commitment are essential to effective program implementation.
More  immediate  economic  and  social  problems,  such  as  the  reemergence  of  regional  and
domestic  economic  instability,  could  divert  policy  makers’  attention  from  the  commitment
needed to enforce improved social and environmental safeguards. ADB experience with earlier
program  loans  to  the  Lao  PDR  indicates  that  it  can  be  difficult  to  sustain  commitments  to
agreed-upon  measures  as  new  priorities  emerge.  However,  ADB’s  experience  in  financing
energy  and  transport  projects  has  also  shown  that  social,  economic,  and  environmental  risks
will  continue  to  be  the  subject  of  high-profile  attention  among  both  national  and  international
stakeholders. Sustained and regular dialogue, solid analysis of the longer term benefits of social
safeguards  and  environmental  management,  consultative  mechanisms  with  funding  agencies
and civil society, and public awareness raising are built into the program design to help maintain
political commitment and to reduce the risk of ineffective implementation. ADB and Government
monitoring  of  the  Program  needs  to  extend  beyond  routine  monitoring  to  entail  an  ongoing
process of assessment to ensure the continued relevance and effectiveness of program actions.

112.
There are no blueprints for developing appropriate policies and institutions to effectively
design and enforce environmental and social safeguards for energy and transport development.
Instruments  and  best  practices  are  evolving  and  need  to  be  adapted  to  local  conditions  and
constraints.  In  addition,  it  can  be  expected  that  weak  institutional  capacity  and  limited  human
resources  in  the  Lao  PDR  will  handicap  efforts  to  properly  address  environmental  and  social
impacts. Against this backdrop, the Program reflects an incremental approach that is tailored to
the  realities of limited implementation capacity, and  the  need  to  introduce  policy reforms in a

 31

structured  and  sequential  fashion.  The  Program  builds  on  substantial  TA  that  has  laid  the
groundwork  for  the  policy  reforms  and  built  the  capacity  to  implement  them.  The  Program  will
also  benefit  from  the  ongoing  TA  (footnote  14)  that  will  allow  the  Government  to  tailor  policy
responses during implementation. The Program has been designed to combine both immediate
policy  actions,  where  there  is  sufficient  basis  to  proceed,  and  flexibility  to  progressively  adapt
and  expand  initiatives  in  response  to  increased  information,  implementation  lessons,  and
international  experiences.  An  example  is  the  restructuring  of  environmental  and  social  units
within  sectoral  agencies  in  the  short  term,  supplemented  by  a  broader  review  of  overall
institutional arrangements for environmental management during program implementation.

113. Effective  environmental  management  and  rigorous  enforcement  of  environmental  and
social  safeguards  will  require  the  continued  allocation  of  adequate  resources  across  a  wide
spectrum  of  activities,  from  public  awareness  campaigns  to  community-based  resource
management  and  biodiversity  conservation,  as  well  as  to  more  specialized  social  and
environmental regulatory functions in central, sectoral, and provincial government agencies. To
minimize  the  risk  of  insufficient  resource  allocation,  the  Program  includes  measures  to
strengthen  monitoring  of  compliance  with  social  and  environmental  safeguards,  studies  on
longer term resource needs, priority setting within provincial environmental action plans, a range
of  measures  and  mechanisms  aimed  at  ensuring  sustainable  finance  for  environmental
management  and  social  safeguards,  and  the  priority  allocation  of  counterpart  funds  for
Program-related activities. In addition, program measures to track environmental allocations in
the  annual  budgetary  process  will  allow  greater  transparency  and  will  facilitate  continued
dialogue.

Overview and Summary

Experience  in  implementing  transport  and  energy  projects  in  the  Lao  People's
1.

adverse  social  and  environmental  impacts  that  were  not  adequately  anticipated  during
identification  and  formulation  or  were  inadequately  addressed  during  project  construction  and
operation. This has caused unnecessary environmental damage and human hardship, and has
weakened investor and funding agency confidence. These problems have arisen because of (i)
weak policy and regulatory mechanisms; (ii) inadequate attention to the environment and social
issues  in  sector  and  project  planning;  (iii)  inadequate  involvement  of  civil  society  in  planning,
implementation,  and  monitoring  activities;  (iv)  weak  enforcement  of  regulations  and  contract
agreements  dealing  with  environmental  and  social  safeguards;  (v)  weak  capacity  of
implementation and monitoring agencies; and (vi) lack of sustainable financing mechanisms.

The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  experience  with  policy-based  lending  in  the  Lao

agriculture and finance sectors. Among the key lessons from program lending to the Lao PDR

(vi) focus reform efforts on a manageable package of priority reforms that are critical to realizing
program  objectives,  (vii)  sequence  and  integrate  reforms  within  the  national  development
agenda,  (viii)  recognize  limited  national  capacity  to  monitor  program  implementation,  and  (ix)

Sectoral Planning, Project Design, and Impact Assessment

a. 

Integrated Area-Based Planning and Sectoral Planning

6.
Transport  and  energy  developments  have  often  taken  place  with  inadequate  account
taken of existing and planned developments, natural resource concentrations (e.g., biodiversity
areas, water sources, mineral deposits, cultural sites), existing land use, and local institutional
capacity during infrastructure planning. This increases costs and causes that potential beneficial
synergies  to  be  lost,  reducing  economic  and  financial  returns.  Efforts  to  minimize  social  and
environmental  impacts  at  the  project  level  must  begin  at  the  time  that  sectoral  strategies  and
programs are being formulated (i.e., at project identification), when location and design changes
can  take  place  at  minimal  cost.  Addressing  social  and  environmental  concerns  during  energy
sector planning can facilitate identification of least-cost options. This is crucial when significant
resettlement  may  be  required  or  when  cumulative  downstream  impacts  might  affect  major
income-generating  activities  such  as  agriculture,  which  will  require  significant  compensation
costs.  The  recent  Hydropower  Development  Strategy  Study  is  a  useful  and  precedent-setting
study for the Lao PDR using this approach, but additional work is required.

b. 

Inconsistent Project-Level Social and Environmental Assessments

7.
The quality and implementation of social and environmental assessments have a major
bearing on whether road or hydropower projects achieve their development goals. The quality of
social and environmental impact assessments and resettlement plans vary greatly because of
inadequate  time,  expertise,  and  limited  funding.  Presently,  projects  funded  by  bilateral  and
multilateral sources generally require higher quality assessments, but even these assessments
vary  greatly  in  quality.  With  the  promulgation  of  the  EPL,  and  the  planned  issuance  of
regulations  and  other  supporting  instruments,  all  projects  will  be  required  to  meet  the  same
national standards and undergo the same authorizing procedures, depending on the magnitude
and scale of the project.

c. 

Adequacy of Baseline Information

8. 
In  the  past,  many  transport  and  energy  projects  were  identified  and  designed  with
inadequate social, environmental, economic, institutional, spatial information in terms of (i) data
availability,  (ii)  accessibility  of  existing  data,  (iii)  data  accuracy,  (iv)  capacity  to  integrate  data
into  early  design,  and  (v)  ability  to  identify  and  fill  key  data  gaps.  Integrated  area  planning
requires  such  information  to  be  available  prior  to  initiating  any  major  future  infrastructure
development. Given that implementation of area-based planning processes will take time, and
that there are pressing infrastructure development needs, the priority is to ensure that planners

and designers are able to access existing information and minimum data sets for all provinces
so that sectoral planning can be based on more than episodic studies.

9.
During the past decade, databases established in central and sectoral agencies to meet
the discrete needs of particular agencies proliferated. Lack of a national coordination framework
has  resulted  in  compatibility  problems,  overlaps  in  data  collection,  differences  in  data
definitions,  and  inadequate  cataloguing  of  information.  This  perpetuates  the  inefficient  use  of
scarce financial and human sources. There is no national reference point enabling planners to
readily  locate  databases.  Data  collection  standards  are  largely  absent.  Data  collection  and
storage  need  to  be  coordinated  and  standardized  so  that  data  are  accessible  and  useful  to
planners  and  decision  makers.  Initial  steps  have  been  taken  with  the  establishment  at  the
National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute of a database with information on forestry,
soils/land  use/land  capability,  watersheds,  and  protected  areas.  However,  a  high-level
coordinated  effort  is  required  to  develop  a  rational  and  structured  national  information
management system that brings databases under common rules and definitions.

3.

Public Involvement

10.
Public  involvement  during  planning,  construction,  and  implementation  stages  has  been
carried out with no national guidelines to direct the process. STEA has informally used United
Nations/Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific  guidelines  for  public
consultations,  but  these  are  not  practiced  universally  in  the  transport  and  energy  sectors.
Consequently,  planners  often  failed  to  fully  understand  project  impacts  on  local  residents  and
village  life.  Villagers  and  non  government  organizations  have  an  in-depth  knowledge  of  local
resources,  capacities,  and  development  needs  that  can  help  to  improve  project  benefits  and
avoid  negative  impacts  when  identified  early  through  consultation.  At  a  broader  level,  the
changing regulatory and institutional environment means that people often are unaware of their
rights  and  responsibilities.  Getting  this  message  to  people  (and  potential  project  owners,
contractors,  and  consultants)  throughout  the  country  needs  to  be  undertaken.  Heightened
awareness by the population of their rights and responsibilities can help increase transparency
and facilitate compliance.

4.

Compliance and Monitoring

11.
Compliance with and monitoring of social and environmental regulations in infrastructure
development remain weak. Effective compliance and monitoring of major infrastructure projects
are  particularly  vital  in  the  Lao  PDR  because  the  projects  are  often  located  in  remote  areas
where  communities  live  at  a  subsistence  level,  and  where  there  are  often  important  biological
resources.

12.  When a dispute arises with the contractor or project owner, the reference point is not the
EIA  or  environmental  action  plan  per  se,  but  the  contracts  entered  into  by  the  parties.  The
Government  and  funding  agencies  have  faced  difficulties  in  forcing  compliance,  as  detailed
management  measures  normally  are  not  included  in  the  various  contractual  documents,  such
as  tenders,  bills  of  quantity,  concession  agreements,  and  financial  documents.  Consequently,
impacts often go unmitigated and uncompensated unless additional funds are provided or until
sufficient  other  pressure  is  brought  to  bear  on  the  offending  party,  by  which  time  the  damage
may be significant. Thus, environmental management plans and social action plans need to be
clearly  incorporated  in  contractual  documents,  with   penalties   for   noncompliance  that  are

sufficiently  strong  to  ensure  that  compliance  is  in  the  best  interest  of  the  contractor  or  project
owner.

13.
Regular  supervision  and  monitoring  are  just  as  important  for  social  and  environmental
impacts  as  for  the  engineering  aspects  of  project  construction.  Otherwise,  small,  easily
remedied  problems  can  become  major  problems  requiring  costly  remedial  measures.
Supervision  and  monitoring  of  social  and  environmental  programs  require  expertise  that  is
mostly  lacking  in-country.  Where  project  supervisory  and  monitoring  staff  perceive  that
monitoring results may lead to recommendations for additional mitigation requiring funding from
project contingencies, or that rectifying problems may delay construction schedules, there is a
strong tendency to put monitoring in abeyance or to ignore or rationalize monitoring results.

Independent  monitoring  in  the  Lao  PDR  has  been  limited  to  a  few  projects,  but  has
14.

local perspective has contributed to improved performance. Monitoring by local people can be a
cost-effective  way  to  identify  impacts  early  before  they  get  out  of  hand.  Effective  supervision
and  reporting  procedures  must  be  clearly  identified  and  undertaken  by  trained  professionals.
The ultimate objective should be to build an indigenous capacity for supervision and monitoring,
though the need for independent monitoring of large, complex projects will always remain.

Sustainable Financing

18.
Sustainable  financing  is  needed  to  redress  most  of  the  cited  deficiencies.  This  is
especially  true  for  up-front  planning  (e.g.,  river  basin  planning),  studies  (e.g.,  fisheries),  and

designs avoid or minimize adverse impacts and allow major environmental and social costs to
be  included  in  project  costs,  and  thus  be  borne  by  the  project  owners  rather  than  being
externalized.  Funds  are  also  required  to  develop  the  human  resources  needed  for  social  and
environmental  management,  to  promote  greater  public  involvement  and  awareness,  and  to
support  independent  compliance  monitoring.  Funds  could  also  address  long-term  and

19.

environmental  protection  and  environmental  programs.  Currently  it  is  not  possible  to  relate

the funds to meet these expenditures were derived.

C.

Recent Experiences and Lessons from Policy-Based Lending

20.
ADB has financed four program loans to the Lao PDR: two to support agriculture sector
reforms, and two to support financial sector reforms. ADB experience with policy-based lending
in the Lao PDR has been partly satisfactory. While there have been implementation delays and
some  policy  reversals,  program  loans  have  helped  push  forward  some  important  policy  and
institutional reforms in the agriculture and finance sectors.  A  recent  ADB  evaluation  of  the
second  agriculture  program  loan  concluded  that  the  agreed-upon  policy  reforms  were
implemented  and  that  agriculture  production  increased,  but  that  there  was  concern  about  the
sustainability  of  the  policy  measures  and  the  program  was  rated  as  only  partly  successful.
Lessons  learned  from  the  program  include  the  need  to  (i)  allow  longer  lead  time  for  reform
measures  that  depend  on  the  issuance  of  new  legislation  or  regulation,  (ii)  take  into  account
institutional capacity when designing privatization programs, (iii) focus policy reforms on fewer
reforms  that  can  realistically  be  implemented,  (iv)  recognize  the  executing  agency  monitoring
capacity  in  the  program  design,  and  (v)  establish  performance  criteria  to  facilitate  program
assessment.

PARTICIPATORY PLANNING PROCESSES

1.
The  overall  design  of  the  loan  and  the  development  of  the  policy  matrix  involved  and
reflect extensive consultations with stakeholders at the national, regional, and community levels.
Public  consultations  were  undertaken  to  obtain  information  related  to  experiences  and
involvement  with  large  infrastructure  projects,  especially  hydropower  and  roads.  Particular
emphasis was given to consultation with stakeholders that share common concerns within the
energy and transport sectors. Issues discussed at all levels focused on how to improve social
and environmental management based on current practice and past experience.

2.
At  the  national  level,  workshops,  interviews,  and  discussions  were  held  with  numerous
Government  agencies,  funding  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  other
interested parties from the start of the project to consider relevant issues and constraints in the
sector, and to develop a potential policy matrix. The national workshops included presentations
of  the  evolving  drafts  of  the  policy  matrix  and  preliminary  findings  from  regional  and  local
consultations.  A  consensus-building  approach  was  adopted  for  developing  the  program  loan
and the policy matrix.
